skill.name: schema-markup
skill.description: When the user wants to add, fix, or optimize schema markup and structured data on their site. Also use when the user mentions "schema markup," "structured data," "JSON-LD," "rich snippets," "schema.org," "FAQ schema," "product schema," "review schema," or "breadcrumb schema." For broader SEO issues, see seo-audit.
skill.summary: Add, fix, or optimize schema markup and structured data for search engines. Implements JSON-LD for rich results.
skill.author: coreyhaines31

security_audit.summary: All static findings are false positives. This is a documentation-only skill containing markdown with JSON-LD schema examples. No executable code, network calls, or security risks exist in the skill content.

content.user_title: Add Schema Markup for Rich Results
content.value_statement: Websites often miss structured data that helps search engines understand content. This skill implements JSON-LD schema markup following Google's guidelines to enable rich results like product cards, FAQ accordions, and event displays in search.
actual_capabilities: Implements JSON-LD schema markup for 10+ schema types including Product, FAQ, Article, and Organization
Follows Google's structured data guidelines for eligibility in rich results
Creates valid schema that passes Google Rich Results Test validation
Combines multiple schema types on a single page using @graph
Provides implementation patterns for static sites, React/Next.js, and WordPress
limitations: Does not modify live website files directly - outputs schema code for manual implementation
Does not access external APIs or validate URLs exist
Cannot guarantee rich result appearance as this depends on overall site quality
Does not analyze existing schema for errors - requires explicit request to review

use_cases.title: E-commerce Product Schema
use_cases.description: Add Product schema with offers, ratings, and reviews to enable product rich cards in search results showing price, availability, and aggregate ratings.
use_cases.target_user: E-commerce site owners and SEO specialists

use_cases.title: FAQ Page Markup
use_cases.description: Implement FAQPage schema so questions and answers appear as expandable accordion items directly in search results, increasing click-through rates.
use_cases.target_user: Content marketers and FAQ page managers

use_cases.title: Local Business Schema
use_cases.description: Add LocalBusiness schema with address, hours, and geo-coordinates to help local businesses appear in map packs and local search results.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Product Schema
prompt_templates.prompt: Add product schema markup for a product page. The product name is 'Premium Wireless Headphones', price is $199.99, it has 4.8 stars from 245 reviews, and the image is at https://example.com/headphones.jpg.
prompt_templates.scenario: Creating product schema for an e-commerce page

prompt_templates.title: FAQ Page Implementation
prompt_templates.prompt: Create FAQPage schema for a page with these questions and answers: 'What is your return policy?' and 'How long does shipping take?'
prompt_templates.scenario: Implementing FAQ schema for a product or support page

prompt_templates.title: Organization with Social Profiles
prompt_templates.prompt: Create Organization schema for 'Acme Inc' with logo at https://example.com/logo.png, include Twitter, LinkedIn, and Facebook profile links.
prompt_templates.scenario: Adding brand schema with social media connections

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Schema Page
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a combined schema for a blog post page that includes Organization, WebSite with SearchAction, and Article schema types linked together.
prompt_templates.scenario: Implementing multiple connected schema types for a complex page

output_examples.input: Add FAQ schema for a page with these Q&A pairs: 'What is your shipping policy?' with answer about free shipping over $50, and 'Can I return items?' with answer about 30-day returns.
output: "text": "We offer free shipping on all orders over $50. Standard shipping takes 3-5 business days."
"text": "Yes, we offer a 30-day return policy for all unused items in original packaging."

output_examples.input: Create Product schema for a book named 'The Art of Coding' by author 'Jane Smith', priced at $24.99, with 4.5 stars from 89 reviews.
output: "description": "A comprehensive guide to modern programming practices.",

output_examples.input: Add Event schema for a webinar titled 'SEO Best Practices 2024' starting June 15, 2024 at 2pm UTC, held online, tickets are $49.

best_practices: Validate all schema with Google Rich Results Test before deploying to production
Ensure schema accurately reflects visible page content to avoid manual action penalties
Use @graph to combine multiple schema types that reference each other using @id
Keep schema updated when page content changes to maintain accuracy
anti_patterns: Marking up content that does not exist on the page (hidden text violates guidelines)
Using schema types not supported by Google for the intended rich result
Self-serving reviews or ratings that violate schema guidelines
Forgetting to update schema when product prices or availability change

faq.question: What is schema markup?
faq.answer: Schema markup is structured data vocabulary (schema.org) that you add to HTML to help search engines understand your content better. It can enable rich results like product cards, FAQ accordions, and star ratings in search.

faq.question: What format should I use for schema?
faq.answer: Google recommends JSON-LD format for structured data. It is placed in script tags in the HTML head or body and is easier to implement and maintain than microdata.

faq.question: Will schema guarantee rich results?
faq.answer: No. Schema markup makes your page eligible for rich results, but Google considers many factors including overall page quality, mobile-friendliness, and content relevance.

faq.question: How do I test if my schema works?
faq.answer: Use the Google Rich Results Test (search.google.com/test/rich-results) to validate your schema. You can also check schema.org/validator and monitor Search Console for enhancement reports.

faq.question: Can I use multiple schema types on one page?
faq.answer: Yes. You can use @graph to combine multiple schema types on one page. This is common for pages that need Organization, WebSite, and Article schema all connected.

faq.question: What happens if my schema has errors?
faq.answer: Schema errors can prevent rich results from appearing. Fix errors promptly by checking Google's documentation for the specific schema type and ensure all required properties are included with valid values.
